data.text:
Two Georgia law schools are once again on National Jurist‚Äôs list of the country‚Äôs ‚ÄúBest Value Law Schools,‚Äù with one topping the rankings. After spending the past two years ranked second, the University of Georgia School of Law (UGA) is back atop the list, and the Georgia State University College of Law (GSU) was listed as a law school with an A- grade. The rankings were announced last week in an article posted to the National Jurist‚Äôs website. UGA was ranked No. 2 behind Brigham Young University‚Äôs J. Reuben Clark Law School the previous two years after being first from 2018-20. BYU was No. 2 this year. . . . #admissions #lawschool #LSAT #testprep #jobposting #hardskills #softskills #legalcareer #careergrowth #lawstudent #hiring #resumewriting #lawfirms #atlantalawyer #legalrecruiting #AtlantaLegalRecruiters #theRMNagency #legalrecruitingfirm #legalrecruiter #legalrecruiters #legalsearch #atlantalegalrecruiters #atlantalawfirms #biglaw #smalllawfirm #inhousecounsel #associate #partner

How Can College Students Get Accepted to a Top Law School? Find out tomorrow at a special conversation with admissions deans at two leading law schools! Join us on November 9 at 12:00pm to hear from Ann Killian Perry, Associate Dean of Admissions and Financial Aid at the University of Chicago Law School, and Sarah Zearfoss, Senior Assistant Dean at the University of Michigan Law School. At this session, you'll have the opportunity to: ‚úÖ Learn about the law school admissions process ‚úÖ Hear what Dean Perry and Dean Zearfoss look for in applicants ‚úÖ Ask the deans any questions you have about law school and the application process Use the link below in the comments to register. #uchicago #career #law

Meet Megan Penn What advice would you give to incoming law students? You miss 100% of the shots you don‚Äôt take. Never let the belief that you can‚Äôt do something keep you from trying. Your own capability might surprise you. Undergraduate Institution: University of Maryland Why did you choose Duquesne Kline School of Law? I chose Duquesne Kline because of the amazing scholarship opportunities. Additionally, the high bar passage rate was important to my decision because I want to be successful inside and outside law school. What is your favorite law school class, and who is your favorite professor? My favorite law school class was Civil Procedure and Professor Richard Heppner is my favorite teacher. What work experiences have you had? I am a Law Clerk for J.P. Ward & Associates and a Research Assistant for Professor Bruce Ledewitz. What student organizations or publications are you involved in? Law Review, Moot Court, Lambda, National Lawyer‚Äôs Guild, Student Ambassador. Questions? We are always happy to help! lawadmissions@duq.edu #KlineLawDuquesne #Pittsburgh #DuquesneUniversity #LawSchool

Sharing something invaluable! Hello LinkedIn community! As I reflect on my own law school journey, I wish I had stumbled upon this comprehensive guide earlier. It's an 86-page treasure trove of wisdom, specifically designed to help law students navigate their academic path with finesse. I know firsthand the challenges that come with this journey, which is why I'm excited to share this resource with all of you. Let's invest in ourselves and each other for a successful and fulfilling legal education. Here's to acing our law school journeys! Source - https://lnkd.in/d-gt3FSq #LawSchoolJourney #lawstudents #StudentSuccess

My favorite class in law school? Federal civil procedure. It seemed relatively straight forward back then, and turns out it actually is. There's one set of rules to know. Need to figure out procedure? Find the relevant rule; check district and judge's rules for quirks; verify with case law to figure out weird situations; rinse and repeat. Enter New York state practice. It was a good day when I finally felt comfortable enough with the quirks of the CPLR and county-specific rules. That knowledge provides a real home-field advantage. Getting there wasn't easy, and mistakes were my wingmen, especially as a very young lawyer. I mean, did a Queens County clerk mark my motion to admit an out-of-state colleague pro hac vice in Queens County off-calendar because the return time on my notice of motion was off by A HALF HOUR since a particular judge preferred slightly later calendar calls on Fridays? Yes! But the point is I learned a lesson that day, and I'm still definitely not salty about that one. Now in Florida, I've had to learn more procedural quirks and lingo. I'm not a young lawyer anymore, so the learning curve has been much smoother. But, there have been a few days that made me feel like a rookie again. It's been fun, however, getting to appreciate the differences. No such thing as a motion for summary judgment in lieu of complaint here? Got it. I choose my own hearing date? Awesome. It also really helps to know wise local practitioners that are lifesavers for my most basic questions. As for the pic, I wish I could say he was starting his legal education early, but in reality, he was just making fun of dad! üìöüèõÔ∏èü§™ #LegalLife #FromNYtoFL #LearningCurve #lawpractice #civilprocedure
